elements.content: The first anionic N-heterocyclic dicarbene−borane binuclear complexes, Li+·[H3B:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHC:BH3}]− (V) and Li+(THF)3·[H3B:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHC:BEt3}]− (VI), were synthesized by combining BH3·THF with [:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHCLi}] n (III) and (THF)2Li:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHC(BEt3)} (IV), respectively. X-ray crystal structures of a (V·THF) n polymer, a V·(DME)2 monomer, a (V·DME)2 dimer, and a VI monomer were obtained. The nature of the bonding of V and VI was probed further by computations.
elements.clean_text: The first anionic N-heterocyclic dicarbene-borane binuclear complexes, Li+⋅[H3B:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHC:BH3}]- (V) and Li+(THF)3⋅[H3B:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHC:BEt3}]- (VI), were synthesized by combining BH3⋅THF with [:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHCLi}] n  (III) and (THF)2Li:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHC(BEt3)} (IV), respectively. X-ray crystal structures of a (V⋅THF) n  polymer, a V⋅(DME)2 monomer, a (V⋅DME)2 dimer, and a VI monomer were obtained. The nature of the bonding of V and VI was probed further by computations.

elements.content: Arduengo’s remarkable discovery two decades ago of adamantyl-functionalized imidazol-2-ylidene (I) (Figure ) as a persistent carbene rapidly blossomed into the burgeoning field of N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) chemistry. These highly versatile NHC ligand systems have found extensive utility in organic and transition-metal catalysis and, most recently, in the surprising stabilization of highly reactive, low-oxidation-state, main-group molecules. With innovative efficiency, chemists have begun to further extend the capabilities of NHCs. In addition to ubiquitous normal NHC, where the carbene carbon center resides between the two nitrogen atoms (C2), a series of intriguing abnormal (aNHC) and remote (rNHC) carbene ligands (also called mesoionic carbenes (MICs) since they cannot be represented by a covalent structure without polarized positive and negative charges) have also been discovered and already are exhibiting promising applications. Among these, the first crystalline metal-free aNHC (II) (Figure ) synthesized by Bertrand is particularly noteworthy.
elements.clean_text: Arduengo's remarkable discovery two decades ago of adamantyl-functionalized imidazol-2-ylidene (I) (Figure ) as a persistent carbene rapidly blossomed into the burgeoning field of N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) chemistry. These highly versatile NHC ligand systems have found extensive utility in organic and transition-metal catalysis and, most recently, in the surprising stabilization of highly reactive, low-oxidation-state, main-group molecules. With innovative efficiency, chemists have begun to further extend the capabilities of NHCs. In addition to ubiquitous normal NHC, where the carbene carbon center resides between the two nitrogen atoms (C2), a series of intriguing abnormal (aNHC) and remote (rNHC) carbene ligands (also called mesoionic carbenes (MICs) since they cannot be represented by a covalent structure without polarized positive and negative charges) have also been discovered and already are exhibiting promising applications. Among these, the first crystalline metal-free aNHC (II) (Figure ) synthesized by Bertrand is particularly noteworthy.

elements.content: Imidazole-based normal carbene (I), abnormal carbene (II), and anionic dicarbene (III).
elements.clean_text: 1  Imidazole-based normal carbene (I), abnormal carbene (II), and anionic dicarbene (III).

elements.content: A free ligand containing both normal (I) and abnormal (II) carbene centers in the same five-membered imidazole ring is a fascinating prospect. Although Bertrand reported a novel triazole-based dicarbene−silver polymer, the corresponding free dicarbene ligand was not reported. This laboratory recently synthesized the first anionic N-heterocyclic dicarbene (NHDC, III) (Figure ), [:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHCLi}] n , by lithiation of the NHC ligand L: (L: = :C{N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)CH}2). Significantly, III bears both normal (C2) and abnormal (C4) carbene centers.
elements.clean_text: A free ligand containing both normal (I) and abnormal (II) carbene centers in the same five-membered imidazole ring is a fascinating prospect. Although Bertrand reported a novel triazole-based dicarbene-silver polymer, the corresponding free dicarbene ligand was not reported. This laboratory recently synthesized the first anionic N-heterocyclic dicarbene (NHDC, III) (Figure ), [:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHCLi}] n , by lithiation of the NHC ligand L: (L: = :C{N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)CH}2). Significantly, III bears both normal (C2) and abnormal (C4) carbene centers.

elements.content: Reaction of III with group 13 Lewis acids (BEt3 and AlMe3) exclusively afforded coordination at the abnormal carbene center (C4), resulting in ((THF)2Li:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHC(LA)}, LA = AlMe3, BEt3 (IV)). This behavior is consistent with the relatively strong interaction between the Li+ cation and the anionic imidazole ring. Might ligand III bind two Lewis acids, thereby demonstrating dicarbene behavior? Herein, we report the syntheses, X-ray structures, and computations of the 1:2 NHDC−borane adducts Li+·[H3B:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHC:BH3}]− (V) and Li+(THF)3·[H3B:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHC:BEt3}]− (VI). These complexes are the first examples of a single anionic imidazole ligand bindingsimultaneouslyto two Lewis acids. The significance of this finding is also underscored by emerging synthetic applications of NHC:BH3 complexes in ionic, organometallic, and radical reactions and the interesting discovery of η1-end-on-coordinated NHC·BH3−transition-metal complexes.
elements.clean_text: Reaction of III with group 13 Lewis acids (BEt3 and AlMe3) exclusively afforded coordination at the abnormal carbene center (C4), resulting in ((THF)2Li:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHC(LA)}, LA = AlMe3, BEt3 (IV)). This behavior is consistent with the relatively strong interaction between the Li+ cation and the anionic imidazole ring. Might ligand III bind two Lewis acids, thereby demonstrating dicarbene behavior? Herein, we report the syntheses, X-ray structures, and computations of the 1:2 NHDC-borane adducts Li+⋅[H3B:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHC:BH3}]- (V) and Li+(THF)3⋅[H3B:C{[N(2,6-Pri 2C6H3)]2CHC:BEt3}]- (VI). These complexes are the first examples of a single anionic imidazole ligand bindingsimultaneouslyto two Lewis acids. The significance of this finding is also underscored by emerging synthetic applications of NHC:BH3 complexes in ionic, organometallic, and radical reactions and the interesting discovery of η1-end-on-coordinated NHC⋅BH3-transition-metal complexes.

elements.content: Recently, N-heterocyclic carbenes have been utilized in the stabilization of a borenium cation and boryl anions. Inspired by Nozaki’s recent synthesis of the first boryl-substituted borohydride by reaction of boryllithium with BH3·THF, we found that BH3 similarly inserted into the ionic bonds between the NHDC anion and the lithium cations in III and IV to give the 1:2 NHDC−borane adducts V and VI, respectively (Scheme ). Interestingly, three crystalline forms of V were obtained: (1) the THF-solvated polymer (V·THF) n , (2) the mono-DME-solvated dimer (V·DME)2, and (3) the doubly DME-solvated monomer V·(DME)2. Although NHC:BEt3 (NHC: = :C{NRCH}2, R = Pri, Mes) has been reported to react with BH3·THF to form NHC:BH3 adducts, isolation of VI indicates that the substitution of BH3 for BEt3 does not take place in the reaction of IV with BH3·THF.
elements.clean_text: Recently, N-heterocyclic carbenes have been utilized in the stabilization of a borenium cation and boryl anions. Inspired by Nozaki's recent synthesis of the first boryl-substituted borohydride by reaction of boryllithium with BH3⋅THF, we found that BH3 similarly inserted into the ionic bonds between the NHDC anion and the lithium cations in III and IV to give the 1:2 NHDC-borane adducts V and VI, respectively (Scheme ). Interestingly, three crystalline forms of V were obtained: (1) the THF-solvated polymer (V⋅THF) n , (2) the mono-DME-solvated dimer (V⋅DME)2, and (3) the doubly DME-solvated monomer V⋅(DME)2. Although NHC:BEt3 (NHC: = :C{NRCH}2, R = Pri, Mes) has been reported to react with BH3⋅THF to form NHC:BH3 adducts, isolation of VI indicates that the substitution of BH3 for BEt3 does not take place in the reaction of IV with BH3⋅THF.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Synthesis of NHDC (<bold>III</bold>)−Borane Binuclear Complexes</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr1" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="om-2011-000579_0001.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

In contrast to the different solid-state structures of (V·THF) n , (V·DME)2, and V·(DME)2, their solution 1H and 11B NMR spectra display the same resonance pattern as V. The 11B-coupled 1H resonance of BH3 at the C4 site of V, observed as a quadruplet at 0.53 ppm (1 J = 80 Hz), is in accord with its quartet proton-coupled 11B resonance at −35.2 ppm (1 J = 80 Hz). The 1H resonance of the BH3 at the C2 site, observed as a broad quadruplet at 0.44 ppm (1 J = 85 Hz), is consistent with the quartet 11B resonance at −35.4 ppm (1 J = 85 Hz). Although these features compare well with the reported 1H (0.52 ppm) and 11B (−35.4 ppm) resonances of the L:BH3 complex, they are shifted downfield compared to those for LiBH4 (δH −0.52 ppm; δB −42.0 ppm) and for lithium boryltrihydroborate (δH −0.98 ppm; δB −44.7 ppm). The 1H resonance of BH3 at the C2 site of VI can only be assigned unambiguously as a singlet at 0.25 ppm in the 1H{11B} NMR spectrum. Moreover, the proton-coupled 11B NMR spectrum of VI clearly exhibits both the singlet resonance of BEt3 at −15.3 ppm (the −13.2 ppm resonance for L:BEt3 is similar) and the quartet resonance of BH3 at −35.0 ppm (1 J = 83 Hz) (which compares well with the case for VI).
elements.clean_text: In contrast to the different solid-state structures of (V⋅THF) n , (V⋅DME)2, and V⋅(DME)2, their solution 1H and 11B NMR spectra display the same resonance pattern as V. The 11B-coupled 1H resonance of BH3 at the C4 site of V, observed as a quadruplet at 0.53 ppm (1 J = 80 Hz), is in accord with its quartet proton-coupled 11B resonance at -35.2 ppm (1 J = 80 Hz). The 1H resonance of the BH3 at the C2 site, observed as a broad quadruplet at 0.44 ppm (1 J = 85 Hz), is consistent with the quartet 11B resonance at -35.4 ppm (1 J = 85 Hz). Although these features compare well with the reported 1H (0.52 ppm) and 11B (-35.4 ppm) resonances of the L:BH3 complex, they are shifted downfield compared to those for LiBH4 (δH -0.52 ppm; δB -42.0 ppm) and for lithium boryltrihydroborate (δH -0.98 ppm; δB -44.7 ppm). The 1H resonance of BH3 at the C2 site of VI can only be assigned unambiguously as a singlet at 0.25 ppm in the 1H{11B} NMR spectrum. Moreover, the proton-coupled 11B NMR spectrum of VI clearly exhibits both the singlet resonance of BEt3 at -15.3 ppm (the -13.2 ppm resonance for L:BEt3 is similar) and the quartet resonance of BH3 at -35.0 ppm (1 J = 83 Hz) (which compares well with the case for VI).

elements.content: In the solid state (Figure a), (V·THF) n exhibits a one-dimensional polymeric chain structure, with the THF-solvated Li+ cations bridging two BH3 fragments from two neighboring V units. This indicates that during the reaction of BH3·THF with polymeric III in THF, two BH3 species insert into the two essentially ionic Li−Ccarbene bonds of each monomeric unit of III. Notably, both monomeric V·(DME)2 and dimeric (V·DME)2 cocrystallized in the monoclinic crystal system (Figure b). Such cocrystallization phenomena usually are due to intermolecular hydrogen bonding and may be ascribed here to the weak intermolecular [C−Hδ+···Hδ−−B] dihydrogen interactions involving the ethylene group of DME and BH3. Indeed, the 2.49 Å d H...H value of [C(29A)−H(29D)···H(4A)−B(4)] (Figure S1, ) is comparable to that (2.31−2.52 Å) of dihydrogen bonds in azacyclohexane−borane adducts and even shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii for the [C−Hδ+···Hδ−−B] system (2.65 Å).
elements.clean_text: In the solid state (Figure a), (V⋅THF) n  exhibits a one-dimensional polymeric chain structure, with the THF-solvated Li+ cations bridging two BH3 fragments from two neighboring V units. This indicates that during the reaction of BH3⋅THF with polymeric III in THF, two BH3 species insert into the two essentially ionic Li-Ccarbene bonds of each monomeric unit of III. Notably, both monomeric V⋅(DME)2 and dimeric (V⋅DME)2 cocrystallized in the monoclinic crystal system (Figure b). Such cocrystallization phenomena usually are due to intermolecular hydrogen bonding and may be ascribed here to the weak intermolecular [C-Hδ+⋅⋅⋅Hδ--B] dihydrogen interactions involving the ethylene group of DME and BH3. Indeed, the 2.49 Å d H...H value of [C(29A)-H(29D)⋅⋅⋅H(4A)-B(4)] (Figure S1, ) is comparable to that (2.31-2.52 Å) of dihydrogen bonds in azacyclohexane-borane adducts and even shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii for the [C-Hδ+⋅⋅⋅Hδ--B] system (2.65 Å).

elements.content: Molecular structures of (a) (V·THF) n polymer and (b) V·(DME)2 monomer and (V·DME)2 dimer. Thermal ellipsoids represent 30% probability; hydrogen atoms on carbon are omitted for clarity. Selected bond distances (Å) and angles (deg) are as follows. For (V·THF) n : B(1)−C(1) = 1.593(3), B(2)−C(3) 1.591(3), C(1)−N(1) = 1.347(2), C(1)−N(2) = 1.357(2), N(1)−C(2) = 1.384(2), N(2)−C(3) = 1.409(2), C(2)−C(3) = 1.341(3); N(1)−C(1)−B(1) = 126.72(18), N(2)−C(1)−B(1) = 128.87(18), C(2)−C(3)−B(2) = 130.60(19), N(2)−C(3)−B(2) = 126.07(18). For V·(DME)2 and (V·DME)2: Li(1)−O(1) = 1.978(9), Li(1)−O(2) = 1.954(9), B(1)−C(1) = 1.602(7), B(2)−C(3) = 1.588(7), B(3)−C(32) = 1.588(8), B(4)−C(34) = 1.596(8); N(1)−C(1)−B(1) = 126.5(5), N(2)−C(1)−B(1) = 128.9(5), C(2)−C(3)−B(2) = 130.9(5), N(2)−C(3)−B(2) = 125.9(4).

The asymmetric unit contains one V·(DME)2 molecule and a half-molecule of (V·DME)2. While two DME molecules chelate to the lithium cation in V·(DME)2, each lithium cation in (V·DME)2 only coordinates to one DME species. Thus, the degree of aggregation of V depends upon the size and number of the coordinating solvents bound to the Li+ cation. In (V ·THF) n , V·(DME)2, and (V·DME)2, each NHDC ligand employs its two carbene centers (i.e., C2 and C4 carbons) to bind to two BH3 molecules. The borons are four-coordinate and adopt near-tetrahedral geometries. (All the BH3 hydrogens were located from difference Fourier maps.) The C−B bond distances (1.588(7)−1.602(7) Å) of V compare well to that (1.585(4) Å) in the L:BH3 complex. Notably, the lithium cations in monomeric V·(DME)2 and in dimeric (V·DME)2 only coordinate selectively to BH3 units at the C4 (i.e., C(3), C(34)) positions of the NHDC ligands. This observation is in accord with the results of our computations on the simplified isomeric C3H3N2(BH3)Li models. Lithium cation attachment to the BH3 at the abnormal carbene site (C4) is 10.7 kcal/mol more stable than Li+ coordination to the BH3 at the normal carbene site (C2). The Li−B distances in V, ranging from 2.189(5) to 2.535(11) Å, are comparble with those (2.441(5) and 2.542(5) Å) reported for lithium boryltrihydroborate.
elements.clean_text: The asymmetric unit contains one V⋅(DME)2 molecule and a half-molecule of (V⋅DME)2. While two DME molecules chelate to the lithium cation in V⋅(DME)2, each lithium cation in (V⋅DME)2 only coordinates to one DME species. Thus, the degree of aggregation of V depends upon the size and number of the coordinating solvents bound to the Li+ cation. In (V ⋅THF) n , V⋅(DME)2, and (V⋅DME)2, each NHDC ligand employs its two carbene centers (i.e., C2 and C4 carbons) to bind to two BH3 molecules. The borons are four-coordinate and adopt near-tetrahedral geometries. (All the BH3 hydrogens were located from difference Fourier maps.) The C-B bond distances (1.588(7)-1.602(7) Å) of V compare well to that (1.585(4) Å) in the L:BH3 complex. Notably, the lithium cations in monomeric V⋅(DME)2 and in dimeric (V⋅DME)2 only coordinate selectively to BH3 units at the C4 (i.e., C(3), C(34)) positions of the NHDC ligands. This observation is in accord with the results of our computations on the simplified isomeric C3H3N2(BH3)Li models. Lithium cation attachment to the BH3 at the abnormal carbene site (C4) is 10.7 kcal/mol more stable than Li+ coordination to the BH3 at the normal carbene site (C2). The Li-B distances in V, ranging from 2.189(5) to 2.535(11) Å, are comparble with those (2.441(5) and 2.542(5) Å) reported for lithium boryltrihydroborate.

elements.content: The X-ray structure of VI shows that the two carbene centers, C2 and C4, of the NHDC ligand coordinate to BH3 and BEt3, respectively (Figure ). In contrast to the structures of V, the Li+ cation in VI coordinates to the BH3 fragment at the normal carbene site (C2) with a B−Li distance of 2.332(6) Å. The B(1)−C(1) bond distance of 1.592(4) Å compares well to those in V (1.588(7)−1.602(7) Å). However, it is 0.07 Å shorter than that (1.662(4) Å) of the B(2)−C(3) bond. The latter is very similar to those in NHC:BEt3 (NHC: = :C{NRCH}2: R = Pri, 1.683(5) Å; R = Mes, 1.678(6) Å).
elements.clean_text: The X-ray structure of VI shows that the two carbene centers, C2 and C4, of the NHDC ligand coordinate to BH3 and BEt3, respectively (Figure ). In contrast to the structures of V, the Li+ cation in VI coordinates to the BH3 fragment at the normal carbene site (C2) with a B-Li distance of 2.332(6) Å. The B(1)-C(1) bond distance of 1.592(4) Å compares well to those in V (1.588(7)-1.602(7) Å). However, it is 0.07 Å shorter than that (1.662(4) Å) of the B(2)-C(3) bond. The latter is very similar to those in NHC:BEt3 (NHC: = :C{NRCH}2: R = Pri, 1.683(5) Å; R = Mes, 1.678(6) Å).

elements.content: Molecular structure of VI. Thermal ellipsoids represent 30% probability; hydrogen atoms on carbon are omitted for clarity. Selected bond distances (Å) and angles (deg): B(1)−C(1) = 1.592(4), B(2)−C(3) = 1.662(4); N(1)−C(1)−B(1) = 125.0(2), N(2)−C(1)−B(1) = 130.7(2), C(2)−C(3)−B(2) = 126.8(2), N(2)−C(3)−B(2) = 130.7(2).
elements.clean_text: 3  Molecular structure of VI. Thermal ellipsoids represent 30% probability; hydrogen atoms on carbon are omitted for clarity. Selected bond distances (Å) and angles (deg): B(1)-C(1) = 1.592(4), B(2)-C(3) = 1.662(4); N(1)-C(1)-B(1) = 125.0(2), N(2)-C(1)-B(1) = 130.7(2), C(2)-C(3)-B(2) = 126.8(2), N(2)-C(3)-B(2) = 130.7(2).

elements.content: The single-point computations and natural bond orbital (NBO) analyses of compounds V·(DME)2 and VI indicate that while the natural charges of Li+ cations approach +1.00 (i.e., +0.89 and +0.91, respectively), the two boron Lewis acid moieties (i.e., BEt3 and BH3) at both normal and abnormal carbene centers of NHDC bear partially negative charges (i.e., in V·(DME)2, −0.61 for BH3 at C4 and −0.53 for BH3 at C2; in VI, −0.49 for BEt3 and −0.63 for BH3) (Figure ), revealing the donor−acceptor bonding character of the interaction between the NHDC ligand and borane moieties. The charge of the boron bound to C2 of NHDC in V·(DME)2 is somewhat (−0.11) more negative than that bound to C4. Notably, the BEt3 boron in VI complexed at the C4 site of the NHDC is of +0.55 positive charge, in contrast to the −0.49 negative charge at the boron atom of BH3.
elements.clean_text: The single-point computations and natural bond orbital (NBO) analyses of compounds V⋅(DME)2 and VI indicate that while the natural charges of Li+ cations approach +1.00 (i.e., +0.89 and +0.91, respectively), the two boron Lewis acid moieties (i.e., BEt3 and BH3) at both normal and abnormal carbene centers of NHDC bear partially negative charges (i.e., in V⋅(DME)2, -0.61 for BH3 at C4 and -0.53 for BH3 at C2; in VI, -0.49 for BEt3 and -0.63 for BH3) (Figure ), revealing the donor-acceptor bonding character of the interaction between the NHDC ligand and borane moieties. The charge of the boron bound to C2 of NHDC in V⋅(DME)2 is somewhat (-0.11) more negative than that bound to C4. Notably, the BEt3 boron in VI complexed at the C4 site of the NHDC is of +0.55 positive charge, in contrast to the -0.49 negative charge at the boron atom of BH3.

elements.content: Selected partial natural charges for V·(DME)2 and VI computed at the experimental geometries.
elements.clean_text: 4  Selected partial natural charges for V⋅(DME)2 and VI computed at the experimental geometries.

elements.content: The dicarbene character of the recently reported deprotonated N-heterocyclic dicarbene (NHDC, III) has been unambiguously demonstrated by the binding of a Lewis acid at both the C2 (normal) and C4 (abnormal) carbene centers. This discovery may serve as a template for a variety of NHDC binuclear complexes.
elements.clean_text: The dicarbene character of the recently reported deprotonated N-heterocyclic dicarbene (NHDC, III) has been unambiguously demonstrated by the binding of a Lewis acid at both the C2 (normal) and C4 (abnormal) carbene centers. This discovery may serve as a template for a variety of NHDC binuclear complexes.
